Family Science.1: Develop an understanding of individuals and families and their relationships to other institutions (e.g., education, governmental, religious and occupational institutions) in a global society.
Family Science.2: Develop cultural competency related to differences in families within the U.S. and around the world.
Family Science.3: Develop the skills to assess interpersonal family relationships as well as family strengths and challenges in order to promote healthy family functioning.
Family Science.4: Understand the decisions facing individuals and families in developing and allocating resources (e.g., time, money, material assets) and how public policies influence these decisions for family well-being.
Family Science.5: Understand historical and contemporary families and their issues.
Family Science.6: Apply best practices, including ethical planning, implementation and evaluation in work with children, youth and families.
